subject: Re: [junit] where there has abstract method in interface
msgSnippet: ... There is one use to leaving the superfluous public abstract modifiers: if you decide to change an interface into an abstract class, or vice versa, it s
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> hxd07 wrote:
> > public interface Test {
> > public abstract int countTestCases();
> > public abstract void run(TestResult result);
> > }
>
> Here, the abstract keyword does nothing useful. It's likely that when
> Kent and/or Erich created this class, Eclipse added the "abstract"
> keyword for them and they never bothered to remove it.
>
> For that matter, the methods don't need to be marked "public" either.

There is one use to leaving the superfluous "public abstract" modifiers:
if you decide to change an interface into an abstract class, or vice
versa, it's one less textual step you need to perform.

Doesn't JUnit predate Eclipse?

David Saff
